article.title: Identifying the progenitors of present-day early-type galaxies in observational surveys: correcting `progenitor bias' using the Horizon-AGN simulation

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 tell us about the accuracy of Horizon-AGN in predicting the early-type fraction of galaxies?
choices: Horizon-AGN perfectly matches the observed early-type fractions across all masses.
Horizon-AGN shows the largest discrepancy with observations at the high mass end.
Horizon-AGN shows reasonable agreement with observations, especially at masses above 10^9.5 solar masses.
Horizon-AGN vastly overpredicts the number of early-type galaxies at all masses.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does the left panel of Figure 3 reveal about the last significant merger redshift of local early-type galaxies in different environments?
choices: Galaxies in low-density environments tend to have their last significant mergers at earlier epochs.
Galaxies in high-density environments tend to have their last significant mergers at earlier epochs.
There is no clear correlation between the last significant merger redshift and the local environment of early-type galaxies.
Galaxies in all environments experience their last significant mergers at approximately the same redshift.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the bottom panel of Figure 4, at redshift ~0.6, what fraction of the stellar mass that ends up in present-day early-type galaxies is contained in progenitors with early-type morphology?
What general trend does Figure 6 depict regarding the progenitor fraction of late-type galaxies as a function of redshift and stellar mass?
choices: The progenitor fraction decreases with increasing redshift and increasing stellar mass.
The progenitor fraction decreases with increasing redshift but increases with increasing stellar mass.
The progenitor fraction remains constant across all redshifts and stellar masses.
The progenitor fraction increases with increasing redshift and increasing stellar mass.
